H0.text: Different body sizes are evidence that donkeys and horses are two different species, given that a donkey and a horse can be bred to produce a mule.

H1.text: A mule is not able to reproduce is evidence that donkeys and horses are two different species, because a donkey and a horse can be bred to produce a mule.

H2.text: They are found in different environments is the observation that provides evidence that donkeys and horses are two different species, because a donkey and a horse can be bred to produce a mule.

H3.text: A mule does not resemble either parent is evidence that donkeys and horses are two different species, because a donkey and a horse can be bred to produce a mule.

A4.text: Mules are nearly always sterile due to the difference in the number of chromosomes between the two parent species.

A5.text: A cross will produce offspring (mule or hinny) with 63 chromosomes, that will not form pairs, which means that they do not divide in a balanced manner during meiosis.
